Energy, Power and Electricity - Electricity - Generation and Transmission/Supply/Distribution of electricity - Electricity procurement contract - Binding effect - Attempt to withdraw therefrom by State instrumentality distribution company - Whether permissible - Such attempt whether vitiated by mala fides in present case - Electricity procurement contract between State distribution company (appellant) and power project of private respondent R-1, where State Government and private respondent had made huge investments and commitments and State Government had helped R-1 to set up a power project - Appellant distribution company, a State instrumentality was obliged and had agreed by its conduct as well as by contracts to purchase 100 % of the power generated by R-1 - Enforcement of, in public interest and on the principle of estoppel - State instrumentality distribution company, held, cannot be permitted to discard the procurement contract and instead purchase electricity from open market at higher prices - State and its instrumentality are required to be guided by public interest and public good and by the touchstone of non-arbitrariness, reasonableness and rationality - IAs of appellant distribution company in OPs, held, adversely affect public good and public interest, and are without any reasonable basis - Said acts of appellant squarely fit in the realm of legal malice or malice in law, though allegations of personal mala tides are not made out - After bifurcation of State of Andhra Pradesh, continuation agreement to purchase power, requiring approval of Andhra Pradesh Electricity Regulatory Commission (State Commission) - Appellant distribution company, a State instrumentality, therefore, had filed OP No. 19 of 2016 before the State Commission for approval of the continuation agreement dt. 28-4-2016 - (Para 50) It is not in dispute that from 1996 till 2007, the project remained in cold storage and HNPCL had initially proposed to revive it. That though HNPCL had initially proposed to give the Government of Andhra Pradesh first right of refusal, in the MoU, to purchase 25 % of the power at regulated tariff, it was at the instance of the State of Andhra Pradesh that it had agreed to supply 100% power to the State through APDISCOMS. Further, though HNPCL had participated in the bidding process conducted by the APCPDCL in the year 2011-2012 and though HNPCL had successfully emerged as L-2 bidder in the said bidding process, it was on account of the decision of the Bid Evaluation Committee, that HNPCL was discarded from the bidding process since the entire generation capacity of HNPCL was encumbered to the State of Andhra Pradesh/APDISCOMS. The minutes of the meeting dated 28-9-2012 of the Bid Evaluation Committee, as has been noticed in the order of the State Commission dated 13-8-2013, clarify this position. (Paras 51 and 83) Records show that the parties had agreed to abide by the conditions mentioned in the amended and restated PPA dated 15-4-1998, except to the extent they may stand modified due to the impact of change in laws/rules and regulated standards guiding such power projects post 1998. However, the documents placed on record clearly show that the State of Andhra Pradesh had, on more than one occasion, expressed that it was interested in buying 100% power from the project of HNPCL. (Paras 84 and 85) The MoA signed between the appellantDISCOMS and HNPCL dated 17-5-2013, would clearly show that it was agreed between the parties that the entire capacity of HNPCL project and all the units of the power stations shall, at all times, be for the exclusive benefit of the DISCOMS and the DISCOMS were to have the exclusive right as well as obligation to purchase the entire capacity from the project. Not only this but after the Reorganisation Act came into effect and the erstwhile State of Andhra Pradesh was bifurcated into the State of Andhra Pradesh and the State of Telangana, the State of Andhra Pradesh, on more than one occasion, reiterated its stand of procuring 100% power from the project of HNPCL. (Para 86) Perusal of the orders of the State Commission dated 26-9-2015 and 6-8-2016, would clearly reveal that the appellant DISCOMS also stood by the position that the 100% power generated in the power plant of HNPCL was to be purchased by them. Not only this, but after the bifurcation of the erstwhile State of Andhra Pradesh, the appellant DISCOMS entered into a continuation agreement dated 28-4-2016, reiterating their stand. (Para 87) After the continuation agreement was entered into on 28-4-2016, the appellant DISCOMS filed OP No. 19 of 2016 for approval of the continuation agreement with the amended and restated PPA of 1998 on 11-5-2016. The State Government again on 1-6-2016, accorded its approval for the purchase of 100% power generated by HNPCL. It could thus be seen that right from the year 2012 till January 2018, it was the consistent stand of the State of Andhra Pradesh as well as the appellant DISCOMS and its predecessors that the appellant DISCOMS were to purchase 100% power generated by HNPCL. (Para 88) It is also not in dispute that in pursuance of the MoA, executed on 17-5-2013, HNPCL had also entered into FSA dated 26-8-2013 with Mahanadi Coalfield Ltd. for the supply of coal for the project. (Para 89) It is thus clear that the consistent stand of the appellant DISCOMS from the year 2012, for the first time, changed on 4-1-2018, when they filed interlocutory applications before the State Commission for withdrawal of OP No. 19 of 2016 and disposal of OP No. 21 of 2015. (Para 90) As such, the stand of the appellant DISCOMS, that the revival of the project of HNPCL was as a Merchant-power plant and therefore, the appellant DISCOMS cannot be compelled to purchase power from it, is self-contradictory. On one hand, HNPCL was discarded from the open bidding process, though it was the successful L-2 bidder, on the ground that 100% power generated by HNPCL is encumbered to the State of Andhra Pradesh/APDISCOMS whereas, on the other hand, it is now sought to be urged that the appellant DISCOMS cannot be compelled to purchase the power from HNPCL, since it was a merchant-power plant. (Para 91) The Court has no hesitation to hold that APTEL has rightly held that, on account of the assurance given by the State of Andhra Pradesh/APDISCOMS, HNPCL had altered its position and as such, it was not permissible for the appellant DISCOMS to withdraw OP No. 19 of 2016. (Para 101) In any case, the conduct of the appellant DISCOMS, in the present case, would disentitle them to withdraw the application. (Para 102) Ground of increase in capital costs not tenable Another argument, that on account of increase of the capital cost of the project, the appellant DISCOMS would be required to purchase power at a much higher rate, also does not hold water. The appellant DISCOMS have themselves reserved their right to contest the correctness of the cost on every component at an appropriate stage before the State Commission. The State Commission, while approving the cost of the project and determining the tariff at which the electricity would be purchased by APDISCOMS from HNPCL, would be required to look into various factors as are stated in Section 61 of the Electricity Act, 2003, so also under the Regulations notified for that purpose. While doing so, the State Commission would be required to take into consideration the various aspects as well as submissions to be made by the appellant DISCOMS and HNPCL. Merely because, the cost of the project is estimated by HNPCL at a particular amount, the State Commission is not bound to accept the same. The State Commission would only approve the cost as it would feel appropriate, as guided by the provisions under Section 61 of the Electricity Act, 2003 and the Regulations. In that view of the matter, the argument in this regard also, is without substance. (Para 103) Tata Power Co. Ltd. v. Reliance Energy Ltd., (2009) 16 SCC 659, relied on No doubt, the Electricity Act, 2003 permits the generating company to supply electricity to a consumer directly, and the generator of an electrical energy is not subject to the grant oflicence, but while supplying electrical energy to a distributing agency, it would be subject to approval and directions of the Commission and the procedures laid down in the Regulations. (Para 107) Duty of State Commission, while granting approval to power purchase agreement ("PPA") While considering grant of approval to the PPA, the State Commission will have to consider whether the PPA, which is subject to approval, subserves the public interest. It will also be required to take into consideration, as to whether the terms agreed are fair and just while granting approval. While exercising power under Section 86(l)(b) of the Electricity Act, 2003, the Commission will have to regulate the price at which the electricity would be procured from the generating companies. Undoubtedly, while doing so, the Commission will be guided by the factors mentioned in Section 61 of the Electricity Act, 2003 and the Regulations concerning the same. Under Section 86(1)(/) of the Electricity Act, 2003, the Commission is also empowered to adjudicate upon the disputes between the licensees and generating companies, and to refer any such dispute for arbitration. (Para 109) Argument based on Section 21 of the Andhra Pradesh Electricity Reform Act, 1998 not tenable Another argument made on the basis of Section 21 of Andhra Pradesh Electricity Reform Act, 1998 ("the Reform Act") is also not tenable. (Para 110) It could thus be seen that any of the agreements mentioned in Section 21(1), (2), a b C d e f g (3) or ( 4) of the Reform Act would be void unless they are made with the consent h of the Commission or subject to such consent. (Para 111) Argument based on Regulations 5.1 and 5.2 of the Tariff Regulations not tenable Regulation 5.2 of the Tariff Regulations deals with determination of tariff. Whereas Regulation 5.1 of the Tariff Regulations provides that where tariff has been determined through transparent process of bidding in accordance with the guidelines issued by the Central Government, the Commission shall adopt such tariff in accordance with the provisions of the Act; Regulation 5.2 of the Tariff Regulations provides that the provisions specified in Part II of the said Regulations shall apply in determining tariff based on capital cost for supply to a distribution licensee. Part II of the Tariff Regulations deals with "filing details" and "tariff determination". (Para 112) Regulation 9 requires that each application where the tariff is to be determined based on capital cost shall include various details duly accompanied by supporting data and documentary and other evidence regarding fixed costs, variable costs and norms of operation, etc. Regulation 10 of the Tariff Regulations requires the tariff to be determined in accordance with the norms specified under the said Regulations, guided by the principles and methodologies specified in the CERC (Terms and Conditions of Tariff) Regulations, 2004, as amended from time to time. The Regulations contain detailed guidelines, as to what shall be the component of tariff and as to how the capital cost and tariff is to be determined. (Para 113) Such an argument at the behest of a party, which has discarded HNPCL from the bidding process, though it had emerged as the successful L-2 bidder, does not hold water and the appellant DISCOMS' approach is of approbate and reprobate. (Para 114) The State Commission has totally erred in dismissing OP No. 21 of 2015 filed by HNPCL, which was filed for determination of capital cost of the project as well as for determination of tariff. A perusal of Section 64 of the Electricity Act, 2003 would reveal that even a generating company is entitled to make an application for determination of tariff under Section 62 of the Electricity Act, 2003. As such, irrespective of the question, as to whether an application for withdrawal of OP No. 19 of 2016 filed by the appellant DISCOMS could have been entertained, the State Commission was wholly unjustified in dismissing OP No. 21 of 2015 filed by HNPCL. In the facts of the present case and, particularly, taking into consideration the conduct of the appellant DISCOMS, APTEL has rightly held that the appellant DISCOMS could not have been permitted to withdraw OP No. 19 of 2016. The question, at this juncture, would be, whether to discard such a project is in the public interest or against it. It may be reiterated, that the determination of the capital cost of the project and the rate of tariff at which the power has to be purchased would always be subject to regulatory control of the State Commission. What has been done by APTEL is only directing the State Commission to determine the same. The impugned judgment of the Tribunal is not prejudicial to the interests of any of the parties.
